file_name: Gilliland v. McGregor Bankruptcy Appeal – Timeliness and Claim Classification.pdf
raw_text:
Gilliland v. McGregor Bankruptcy Appeal –
Timeliness and Claim Classification
Background: This appeal arises from the Chapter 13 bankruptcy of Christopher Blaine McGregor. Creditor
Brittany Gilliland filed a $32,000 proof of claim based on a divorce decree, which the bankruptcy court
ultimately allowed as a general unsecured claim (denying her asserted priority as a domestic support
obligation). In the order on appeal, the court overruled the debtor’s objection to the claim’s timeliness but
sustained the objection as to priority, reclassifying Claim No. 19 as a general unsecured claim 1 .
Gilliland (the ex-wife creditor) contends on appeal that (1) her claim was timely filed under the Bankruptcy
Rules (despite the bar date falling on November 29, 2024), and (2) the $32,000 debt should be treated as a
domestic support obligation (DSO) with priority status (and nondischargeable under §523(a)(5)), rather than
a dischargeable general unsecured debt. Below we analyze each issue, the parties’ arguments, the
bankruptcy court’s reasoning, and the applicable law. We then assess which side is likely to prevail on
appeal and why.
Issue 1: Timeliness of the Proof of Claim Filing
The Bar Date and Rule 9006: In McGregor’s Chapter 13 case, the court set a claims bar date of Friday,
November 29, 2024 2 . Gilliland filed her proof of claim on Monday, December 2, 2024 3 . Normally, a
proof of claim filed after the bar date is untimely and subject to disallowance under 11 U.S.C. §502(b)(9) and
Bankruptcy Rule 3002(c) 4 5 . However, Bankruptcy Rule 9006(a) governs how to compute deadlines and
provides an important exception: if the last day of a filing period falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or “legal
holiday,” then the deadline extends to the next business day 6 7 . A “legal holiday” for these purposes
expressly includes “any other day declared a holiday by the state where the district court is located”
(for time periods measured after an event) 8 7 . Here, the 70-day claims period began with the
bankruptcy filing on September 20, 2024, so day 70 fell on November 29, 2024 9 .
Gilliland’s Argument (Creditor): Gilliland maintained that her December 2 filing was timely because the
bar date (Nov. 29) fell on the Friday after Thanksgiving – a day declared an official state holiday in
Alabama. She introduced a May 20, 2024 memorandum from Alabama’s Governor expressly designating
Friday, Nov. 29, 2024 as a state holiday for state employees 10 11 . Under Rule 9006(a)(6)(C), that state-
declared holiday should extend the deadline to Monday, Dec. 2, the next business day 12 13 . In short, she
argued that November 29 counted as a “legal holiday” in Alabama, so her claim filing on Dec. 2 was within
the extended time 14 15 . The purpose of including state-declared holidays in Rule 9006 is to protect filers
who might assume courts are closed on those days 16 – exactly the scenario here, since Alabama state
offices were closed the day after Thanksgiving.
McGregor’s Argument (Debtor): The debtor countered that November 29, 2024 should not be treated as a
legal holiday for filing purposes. He pointed to Alabama law (Ala. Code § 1-3-8) which enumerates legal
public holidays and delegates to the Governor the designation of “the day for public thanksgiving”
(singular) as a holiday 17 . In other words, the statute contemplates Thanksgiving Day (Thursday) as the
official holiday, and does not automatically recognize the Friday after Thanksgiving as a state holiday.
1
The debtor noted that Governor Ivey did issue a memo giving state employees Friday off, but argued this
was merely an administrative closure of offices, not an addition to the legal holidays list 18 19 . He even
produced the Governor’s formal Thanksgiving Day proclamation (for Thursday, Nov. 28) to emphasize that
only the Thursday was proclaimed as the “day of thanksgiving” under state law. In sum, McGregor’s position
was that a one-time executive memo closing state offices on Nov. 29 did not rise to the level of a “declared
state holiday” under Rule 9006 – thus the bar date should not be extended, and the claim should be
deemed late 20 21 .
Bankruptcy Court’s Ruling: The bankruptcy judge sided with the creditor on this issue. After reviewing the
Alabama statute, the court found that the Governor did have authority to declare an additional legal
holiday. Alabama Code §1-3-8(d) permits the Governor to declare state holidays for special events 22 , and
Governor Ivey’s memorandum “extending the holiday to include both Thursday, November 28, 2024,
and Friday, November 29, 2024” was a valid exercise of that power 23 . Therefore, November 29, 2024
was a legal holiday in Alabama, and under Rule 9006(a)(6)(C) the claims deadline was extended to
Monday, December 2 24 25 . The court noted that the Federal Rules take into account state-declared
holidays to avoid unfairly penalizing filers on days they would reasonably believe the courts (or clerk’s
office) to be closed 16 . Given that conclusion, Gilliland’s proof of claim – filed on Monday, Dec. 2, 2024 –
was deemed timely 26 .
Likely Outcome on Appeal (Timeliness): The district court is likely to affirm the bankruptcy court’s
determination that the claim was timely. Rule 9006(a)’s plain language supports the result: it includes any
holiday “declared by the state” 8 , and the evidence showed Alabama’s Governor expressly declared Nov.
29, 2024 a holiday. The debtor’s technical argument about the Alabama statute’s wording (Thanksgiving
“Day” in the singular) was considered but ultimately rejected by the bankruptcy judge, who found that state
law did permit an extra holiday in this circumstance 22 23 . The district court will review this legal issue
de novo, but the analysis in the record is persuasive. Indeed, the Bankruptcy Rules’ 2009 Advisory
Committee Note confirms that Rule 9006 was amended to treat state holidays as legal holidays to avoid
“unintended late filings” when a filer might assume courts are closed 16 . Here it was objectively reasonable
for Gilliland to assume a filing deadline falling on the Friday after Thanksgiving extended to Monday. Thus,
on the timeliness question, Gilliland’s position is likely to prevail again – the proof of claim was timely
filed 25 .
Issue 2: Classification of the $32,000 Claim – Domestic Support
Obligation or General Unsecured Debt?
Legal Framework: The central dispute is whether the $32,000 that McGregor owes Gilliland (arising from
their divorce decree) is a “domestic support obligation” (DSO) or not. A DSO is a term of art in bankruptcy,
defined in 11 U.S.C. §101(14A) as a debt owed to a former spouse or child that is “in the nature of alimony,
maintenance, or support” (including such obligations established by a divorce decree or agreement) 27 .
If a debt qualifies as a DSO, it is given first priority in payment under 11 U.S.C. §507(a)(1) and is non-
dischargeable in bankruptcy (under §523(a)(5)) – meaning the debtor must pay it in full in a Chapter 13
plan and cannot wipe it out 28 29 . By contrast, a divorce-related debt that is not a support obligation (for
example, a property settlement or equitable distribution payment) is treated as a general unsecured claim.
Such a claim receives no special priority and, in Chapter 13, will often be paid only pro-rata with other
unsecured debts – and can potentially be discharged upon completion of the plan 30 31 . (Notably, Congress
in BAPCPA made domestic support debts non-dischargeable in all bankruptcies, but debts arising from
2
property division remain dischargeable in Chapter 13 unless they qualify as DSOs 32 33 .) The bankruptcy
court below ruled that Gilliland’s $32,000 claim was not a DSO but rather a property settlement debt, and
therefore reclassified it as a general unsecured claim with no priority 34 . Gilliland appeals that ruling,
arguing the court erred and that the debt should be treated as a support obligation in substance.
Gilliland’s Argument (Creditor/Appellant): Gilliland contends that the bankruptcy judge mischaracterized
the nature of the debt. She argues that although the divorce decree labeled the $51,411 payment as part of
the property/equity division, it was fundamentally intended to provide financial support to her. Key points
of her position include:
• Absence of Alimony = Support by Other Means: The divorce decree explicitly states that
“neither party is ordered to pay alimony.” Gilliland argues that this fact, in context, supports her
claim: since no periodic alimony was awarded, the state court’s equitable distribution of assets
(specifically, awarding her half the home equity via payments from McGregor) was meant to serve
as a form of support in lieu of alimony 35 36 . Courts have recognized that property division can be
intended as support where, for example, one spouse forgoes alimony in exchange for a larger share
of marital property 37 38 . Gilliland says that is essentially what happened here.
• Payment Structure Resembles Support: The decree required McGregor to pay the $51,411 in a
particular way: an initial $10,000 lump sum, then $2,000 per month for 21 months 39 40 . Gilliland
emphasizes that this monthly installment structure looks like a stream of support payments.
Instead of a one-time property buyout, the obligation was spread over nearly two years, which is
atypical for a simple property settlement. In her view, the 21-month payment schedule “begins to
look more like alimony,” a point she raised at trial 41 . The regular monthly influx suggests the court
wanted to ensure she had ongoing income for that period.
• Her Financial Need and Reliance: At the bankruptcy hearing, Gilliland testified that she depended
on the $2,000 monthly payments to meet her financial obligations 42 43 . She was, at that time,
struggling to pay bills, and the money from McGregor was used for her living expenses. This, she
argues, shows the payments functioned as support. She also introduced evidence of the parties’
financial disparity at the time of divorce – for example, a child support form (CS-42) indicating
McGregor had a significantly higher income, or that she had fewer assets – to demonstrate she was
the economically disadvantaged spouse 44 45 . In Edwards v. Colin, a case from the same
jurisdiction, the district court stressed the importance of the financial positions of the parties and
found a property settlement was actually support where the wife clearly needed the payments to
maintain herself 46 47 . Gilliland claims a similar dynamic here.
• Case Law – Substance Over Form: Gilliland relies on precedent holding that bankruptcy courts
must look beyond labels and ask whether an obligation is “in the nature of support.” The Eleventh
Circuit’s decision in Cummings v. Cummings is central 48 49 . In Cummings, a divorce judgment
had awarded the ex-wife a large $6.3 million equitable distribution, and no alimony. The Eleventh
Circuit recognized that property awards can serve the function of support, noting that divorce courts
often do not rigidly distinguish the two 37 50 . The Cummings court remanded for clarification, but
emphasized that if the divorce judge intended the asset distribution to enable the wife to support
herself, then it is effectively support 51 52 . Gilliland argues that here, as in Cummings, the
bankruptcy court should have found that the divorce court’s intent was to provide her financial
support through the equity award. She also cites In re Benson (11th Cir. 2011) – an unpublished
3
decision that enumerated eight factors courts consider to differentiate support from property.
Applying those Benson factors (discussed further below), she contends the balance tilts in favor of
finding a support obligation.
• Effect of BAPCPA: Gilliland’s brief points out that the 2005 BAPCPA amendments to the Bankruptcy
Code reinforced protections for ex-spouses. Congress made all divorce-related debts
nondischargeable in Chapter 7 (eliminating the prior distinction between alimony and property
settlements under §523(a)(15)) 53 . While in Chapter 13 a property settlement debt can theoretically
be discharged, BAPCPA did subject Chapter 13 debtors to stricter obligations to pay domestic
support and stay current on them. Gilliland argues that this overall policy shows Congress intended
to prioritize the support of ex-spouses and dependents, and that courts should therefore be
inclined to recognize bona fide support obligations even if they are couched as equitable distribution
54 55 . In her view, treating the equity payment as a DSO would be consistent with the spirit of
BAPCPA – ensuring that a spouse who needs support isn’t harmed by the debtor’s bankruptcy.
(Indeed, if the debt is not a DSO, it could be discharged, leaving her with nothing despite the divorce
award.)
In sum, Gilliland’s position is that the substance and intent of the divorce decree make the $32,000 debt
“in the nature of support.” She urges the appellate court to reverse the classification, arguing that the
bankruptcy judge focused too narrowly on the labels in the decree and ignored the reality of her financial
need and the purpose the payments served 56 57 .
McGregor’s Argument (Debtor/Appellee): McGregor maintains that the bankruptcy court was correct –
the debt is a straightforward property settlement, not alimony or support. He argues that virtually all
objective indicators show a property division rather than a support obligation:
• Clear Language of the Decree: The divorce decree’s text is McGregor’s strongest evidence. In
Paragraph 7 of the decree, the state court ordered McGregor to pay his ex-wife “the sum of
$51,411.21, representing one-half (1/2) of the equity in the residence” 58 39 . The obligation is
explicitly tied to the equity value of a marital asset (the home), not to any assessment of the ex-
wife’s living expenses or financial needs 59 . Just as importantly, the decree unequivocally states
that “[n]either party is ordered to pay alimony.” 60 This was a contested divorce that went to
trial, and the judge clearly decided property division was appropriate but spousal support was not.
McGregor argues that the federal court must give weight to the state court’s explicit decision not to
award alimony 61 62 . The labeling isn’t dispositive, but here the label (“equity in the residence”)
accurately reflects the nature of the debt. In bankruptcy, a court cannot simply re-characterize a
property debt as support based on one party’s after-the-fact claim of need, especially when
the decree itself and both parties at the time treated it as a property division 30 63 .
• Reciprocal Exchange – Property Settlement Hallmarks: The structure of the obligation in the
decree is that of a property buy-out, not support. McGregor notes that upon his payment of the
$51,411 in full, Gilliland is required to execute a quitclaim deed transferring her interest in the
house to him 64 . In other words, she was awarded a monetary sum in exchange for her 50%
interest in a major marital asset (the home) 64 65 . This kind of quid pro quo – money for property
title – is characteristic of property settlements. By contrast, support obligations typically have no
such exchange; they are simply payments for the maintenance of the recipient. Additionally, the
decree provided a specific remedy if McGregor failed to pay the obligation: the house would be sold
4
and the proceeds split equally 66 . Allowing or requiring the sale of the property to satisfy the debt is
a classic enforcement mechanism for dividing property; it is not how support (like alimony or child
support) is enforced, which would usually be through contempt or income withholding, not
liquidating marital assets. The absence of any provision permitting enforcement by contempt or
later modification in the decree is telling: under Alabama law, alimony is subject to modification
and enforceable by contempt, whereas a property division is a fixed debt not subject to
modification 67 60 . The decree’s terms (a fixed sum, no contingencies, no modification) align
squarely with a property settlement 60 .
• No Support Indicators in Decree: McGregor points out that the decree did address support in
another way – it ordered child support to be paid, but by Gilliland to McGregor (since he had
custody of the children) 43 68 . This is the only support obligation in the decree, and it runs
opposite to Gilliland’s claim. The presence of a child support provision for McGregor’s benefit,
coupled with an express “no alimony” clause, underscores that the divorce court did not intend for
McGregor to pay any ongoing support to Gilliland. In fact, the overall judgment suggests Gilliland
was in a relatively stronger financial position: she was the one paying child support (implying she
earned more), and the court may have equalized assets but saw no need for alimony. McGregor
testified in the bankruptcy hearing that Gilliland has a Master’s degree and was earning $60,000–
$80,000 per year, whereas he has no college degree and had assumed significant debts (credit
cards, tax debt) during the marriage 69 70 . By the time of bankruptcy, Gilliland was not working,
but McGregor argued this was by choice, not incapacity, given her qualifications 69 70 . The
bankruptcy judge found that any post hoc reliance by Gilliland on the payments for her expenses did
not transform the nature of the debt – especially since nothing in the divorce record suggested
the money was calculated based on her needs or meant for her support 71 42 .
• Application of the Benson Factors: The debtor urges that when you apply the eight-factor test
often used to distinguish support from property (as outlined in In re Benson 72 ), all or most factors
here point to a property settlement. For example:
• Language of the Agreement/Decree: The decree’s language strongly indicates a property division.
It specifies the payment is for “equity in the residence” and even calls it an “Obligation” related to the
house, not any kind of support or maintenance 58 59 . This factor is firmly in the debtor’s favor 73 .
• Financial Positions of the Parties at the Time: Unlike many support scenarios, the wife (Gilliland)
was not at a clear financial disadvantage at divorce. Evidence showed she had higher earning
potential (a graduate degree and prior solid income) versus McGregor’s lesser education and
earnings 74 75 . The divorce court likely considered these facts when it declined alimony. Thus, the
parties’ financial circumstances do not suggest the $51k was needed to prop up an economically
weaker spouse – if anything, McGregor was the less-advantaged party. This factor favors the
debtor’s view that the payment was part of equitable distribution, not a need-based support award
74 76 .
• Function/Amount of the Obligation: The amount was determined by a 50/50 division of a specific
asset, not by assessing a reasonable support amount for the wife. The $51,411 figure was precisely
half the home equity to the penny 58 , indicating a calculation of property value rather than an
estimation of living expenses. The function was to equalize the division of marital property, not to
provide for the ex-wife’s sustenance 77 78 . This again supports classification as a property debt.
5
• Contingencies (Termination on Death or Remarriage): True support obligations (like periodic
alimony) often cease upon the recipient’s remarriage or either party’s death, by law. Here, the
obligation had no such contingency – McGregor had to pay the full amount regardless of Gilliland’s
marital status or future income 79 . In fact, Gilliland did remarry (briefly, within months of the
divorce) or at least cohabit with a new partner, yet the obligation remained unchanged 80 81 . The
lack of a termination condition is consistent with a fixed property debt. (McGregor pointed out,
somewhat pointedly, that if this were truly “support,” Gilliland’s remarriage and cohabitation under
Alabama law would have terminated any alimony obligation 80 82 – but since it’s property-based,
her remarriage had no effect on the debt.)
• Payment Terms (Frequency and Number of Payments): Gilliland emphasizes the 21 monthly
installments as resembling alimony. McGregor responds that the installment schedule was not to
create a stream of maintenance, but rather to accommodate his ability to pay a large sum. The
decree gave him an option to avoid installments altogether by paying the entire amount within 90
days 40 . If he had, Gilliland would have received a lump sum like a typical property buyout. The only
reason monthly payments occurred was because McGregor elected to pay over time. This suggests
the frequency was dictated by the debtor’s finances (common in property settlements) rather than
the creditor’s ongoing support needs 83 . Also, unlike periodic support, the monthly payments were
for a limited, set period (21 months) with a defined end, not an indefinite obligation.
• Waiver of Other Support Rights: In cases where a property settlement is exchanged for waiving
alimony, courts find support intent. Here, there was no divorce settlement agreement at all – the
case was decided by the judge. Gilliland did not contractually waive alimony rights in return for the
equity payment; rather, the judge independently decided neither party should pay alimony 84 . So
this factor (whether the award was intended to substitute for alimony) leans toward McGregor. There
was no negotiated trade-off of support for property; the property division stood on its own.
• Modifiability and Enforcement: As noted, the obligation was not modifiable and not enforceable
by contempt – features of a property award, not support 67 . Alimony in Alabama can be modified or
ended based on changed circumstances or remarriage (see Ala. Code §30-2-55, §30-2-57), but once a
property division is final, it’s not subject to adjustment 67 . McGregor argues that if Gilliland truly
believed this was support, theoretically she (or the state court) could have sought to modify or
terminate it when she remarried – which didn’t happen. Instead, she treated it as a debt owed to her.
This factor thus favors the debtor’s view as well. (Gilliland would likely counter that because it wasn’t
labeled alimony, she had no ability to seek modification – which is precisely why she wants it
recognized as support now. The debtor’s rejoinder is that you can’t have it both ways: she cannot
claim the benefits of support now without having had them then, and her remarriage highlights the
inconsistency of her position 85 .)
• Tax Treatment of the Payments: Although recent tax law changes render this factor less
informative, historically alimony payments are taxable to the recipient and deductible by the payor,
whereas property settlements have no tax impact. There’s no indication the parties treated these
payments as alimony for tax purposes. Given that after 2018 alimony is no longer tax-deductible,
this factor is essentially neutral or inapplicable here 86 .
Considering all these factors, McGregor argues the debt looks nothing like a support obligation. It looks
exactly like what the decree says it is – a property equalization payment. He also underscores that the
6
bankruptcy court’s finding of fact on this issue (that the divorce court did not intend the payment as
support) is entitled to deference. The standard of review for this kind of determination – the true nature of a
divorce-created debt – is clear error 87 . The bankruptcy judge heard the testimony, weighed the evidence,
and concluded the obligation was a property debt, a decision supported by multiple factual indicia 34 .
McGregor contends that the judge made no mistake, let alone a “definite and firm conviction of error”
needed to overturn a factual finding 87 . In his view, Gilliland is attempting to relitigate the divorce by
injecting a support purpose that simply isn’t reflected in the divorce decree or the parties’ circumstances.
Bankruptcy Court’s Ruling: After a full evidentiary hearing, the bankruptcy court agreed with McGregor.
Judge Creswell found “no indication in the Divorce Decree that the Circuit Court intended the
Obligation to function as support for [Gilliland].” 34 The order emphasized several of the points above:
the debt was explicitly tied to half the equity in the marital residence, the decree even stated no alimony
was awarded, and the overall structure was a property settlement, not support 60 59 . The court noted
that the divorce decree lacked any language or features typically associated with support (such as
being contingent on remarriage or subject to modification), and in fact included a provision for Gilliland to
relinquish her property interest upon payment – confirming it was an exchange of property rights 88 89 .
While Gilliland testified about her need for the money, the court found this post hoc reliance insufficient to
transform the character of the debt 42 . It also found it persuasive that Gilliland was actually paying child
support to McGregor, indicating that if anything, she was not viewed as the dependent spouse financially
68 . In light of all this, the judge concluded the $32,000 (the remaining amount due at bankruptcy) was
part of a property settlement and not a “domestic support obligation” under §101(14A) 34 . She
therefore reclassified the claim as a general unsecured claim with no priority 90 . (Notably, the court
explicitly declined to address dischargeability of the debt under §523(a)(5) or (a)(15), as that issue was not
before it 91 . The focus was purely on claim classification for bankruptcy administration.)
Relevant Precedents and Their Application: The bankruptcy court’s approach closely followed Eleventh
Circuit guidance. The court cited Cummings v. Cummings for the principle that neither the labels used by the
parties nor the divorce court’s characterization is conclusive – what matters is the intent and substance of
the obligation 92 93 . In Cummings, the Eleventh Circuit indeed instructed courts to look beyond the label
(“alimony” vs “property settlement”) to see if a purported property award was intended to provide support
94 95 . In our case, after looking beyond the labels, the judge found no evidence of a disguised support
intent. This contrasts with the Cummings scenario: there, the divorce court had explicitly commented that
the wife could support herself on the assets awarded, suggesting the asset division was serving a support
function 96 95 . Here, the Tallapoosa County divorce court made no similar statements – to the contrary,
it declined any alimony and treated the home equity division in a conventional way 60 62 . The bankruptcy
judge also considered Edwards v. Colin (M.D. Ala. 2017), where a district court reversed a bankruptcy
decision and found a property settlement to be in the nature of support because “there [was] no question
that the intent of the parties was for the settlement to serve as support… in lieu of alimony.” 97 98
That case involved a clear agreement between the divorcing spouses that a property payout was
substituting for alimony. By contrast, in Gilliland’s case there was no mutual intent or agreement – only
the divorce court’s judgment, which gave no indication of a support purpose 84 85 . In In re Benson (11th
Cir. 2011), the Eleventh Circuit affirmed a bankruptcy court’s detailed analysis of multiple factors to decide
support vs. property. We walked through those Benson factors above using the evidence here, and the
result aligns with the bankruptcy court’s conclusion: on factor after factor, the $32,000 obligation looked like
an equalization of assets, not a maintenance obligation. Thus, both the case law and the factual record
support the bankruptcy court’s classification.
7
Likely Outcome on Appeal (Classification): On this issue, McGregor (the appellee debtor) has the stronger
case, and the bankruptcy court’s decision is likely to be upheld. Gilliland’s arguments are not without merit
– there are certainly cases where a lump-sum property award is deemed support in disguise – but those
cases involve facts quite distinct from the ones at hand (e.g. an obvious imbalance of financial power, or
explicit indications that the award was instead of alimony). Here, the evidence of intent weighs against
Gilliland. The divorce decree’s plain terms and the surrounding circumstances strongly suggest a property
division was intended, and the bankruptcy judge’s finding to that effect was well-supported by the record
34 . Given the clear error standard for overturning such factual findings, the district court would need to
be firmly convinced a mistake was made. It is hard to see clear error in Judge Creswell’s careful analysis: she
considered Gilliland’s need but found it insufficient to overcome the concrete factors pointing to a property
debt 99 34 . Moreover, public policy (as reflected in BAPCPA) certainly prioritizes actual domestic support
obligations, but it does not mandate that every equitable distribution be treated as support. Congress
ensured that true DSOs receive priority and are never discharged, whereas other divorce debts (while
still important) do not get the same elevated status. In this case, classifying the claim as general unsecured
does mean Gilliland might not be paid in full through the Chapter 13 plan, but that outcome flows from the
nature of the debt as determined by the state court.
In conclusion, on Issue 1 (Timeliness), the bankruptcy court correctly applied Rule 9006 to find the proof of
claim timely, a decision likely to be affirmed on appeal 26 . On Issue 2 (Classification), the bankruptcy
court’s ruling that the $32,000 debt is not a domestic support obligation was grounded in substantial
evidence and consistent with law, and thus is also likely to be affirmed 34 . Gilliland faces an uphill battle
convincing the district court otherwise. Barring any clear error in the bankruptcy court’s fact-finding,
McGregor’s position should prevail on appeal – the claim will remain classified as a general unsecured
debt (with no priority) rather than a priority domestic support obligation. The likely result is that the
bankruptcy court’s order will be upheld in full, leaving Gilliland with a timely-filed but non-priority claim that
will share in any pro-rata distribution and be subject to discharge upon completion of the Chapter 13 plan
100 .
